Using an integrated approach to assess the sediment quality of an Mediterranean
lagoon, the Bizerte lagoon (Tunisia)

Al-Rawabdeh 4 , Atef Atyaoui 3,5 , Soufiane de Touil 1 , Mohamed Ridha Driss 1 , Jérôme
Cachot 2

Abstract:
The present study investigates the quality of surface sediments from the Bizerte lagoon (North Tunisia) using an
integrated approach including chemical contaminant analysis, bioassays and sediment quality guidelines (SQGs).
Sediment samples were collected at 9 sites and analyzed for eight heavy metals (Hg, Cd, Cr, Cu, Pb, Zn, Ni, Fe
and Mn). PAHs, PCBs, OCPs were measured previously in the same sediment samples. Our results indicated
that the highest concentrations of metals were found near urban areas due to the municipial and industrial
wastewater discharges. Sediment pollution assessment was carried out using geoaccumulation index (Igeo) and
enrichment factor (EF), which indicate a widespread pollution by Cd, Pb, Ni and Zn in the studied sediments.
For bioassays, aqueous and organic extracts were used to assess toxicity and genotoxicity in sediments by using
Microtox ® and SOS Chromotest, respectively. Toxicity levels were compared to metallic and organic pollutants
contents. Our results highlight differences in the pattern of responses between the different assays and show no
correlation with all the studied contaminants, emphasizing the influence of other contaminants not analyzed in
the present study. Based on SQGs, the results of toxicity assessment indicated that adverse effects caused by Ni
and Zn would be expected frequently. Nickel was found to have the highest predicted acute toxicity, followed by
Zn, Pb, Cd, Cu and Cr. There was no significant relationship between sediment toxicity calculated from heavy
metal concentrations (SQG approach) and those measured with bioassays. These findings support the use of
integrated approachs for evaluating the environmental risks of sediments.
Keywords: marine lagoon, surface sediments, metals, organic pollutants, toxicity assays
text.body:
Introduction
Bizerte lagoon (northern coast of Tunisia) represents an ecosystem whose biological balance has been modified
in relation to the anthropogenic development and big industries settlement (about 100 industries). The steel
complex -El Fouledh‖, the petroleum refinery and the cement factory are the main industries settled in the
vicinity of the lagoon. Marine sediments can be suitable indicators for monitoring of past and present
contamination in aquatic environments (Balls et al. 1997; Atgın et al. 2000). They have been found polluted with
various kinds of hazardous and toxic substances (Fukue et al. 1999; Zabetoglou et al. 2002), including heavy
metal which accumulate in sediments. Metals can be discharged in the aquatique environment via several
pathways, including disposal of liquid effluents, terrestrial runoff, and leachates, shipping, as well as
atmospheric deposition (Lamotte et al. 1996; Karageorgis et al. 2002; Mucha et al. 2003). Heavy metal pollution
has become an important issue worldwide due to their high toxicity, abundance and persistence in ecosystems
(Cooke et al. 1990; Lim et al. 2008; Weng et al. 2008; Varol 2011). Heavy metal residues in contaminated
habitats may accumulate in microorganisms, aquatic flora and fauna, which, in turn, may enter into the human
food chain and result in health problems (Cook et al. 1990; Deniseger et al. 1990). The bioavailability of these
contaminants and consequently their toxicity may be strongly influenced by factors such as reduction/oxidation
state, sediment grain size, salinity, pH, and organic matter content, that can change daily due to the natural
dynamics of coastal area (Buccolieri et al. 2006; Choueri et al. 2009). Such accumulation is enhanced in
enclosed and semi-enclosed areas where exchange of water with the open sea is limited (Okay et al. 1996;
Karageorgis et al. 2002).
In response to concerns about chemical pollution and environmental degradation, legislation world-wide has
been implemented to protect and restore ecological quality in estuarine, coastal and marine systems; for instance
the Water Framework Directive (WFD, 2000/60/EC) and the Marine Strategic Framework Directive (MSFD,
2008/56/EC) in Europe. At present, assessment and monitoring of sediment quality in Tunisia, particularly in the
Bizerte lagoon, is predominantly reliant on chemical analyses (Ben Garali et al. 2013; Barhoumi et al. 2014a, b).
Measurement of contaminant concentrations alone is often insufficient to derive accurate conclusions on the
potential toxicity of contaminated environmental samples, as it is virtually impossible to identify and quantify all

potential toxicants. In addition, the magnitude of contamination does not necessarily reflect a similar level of
ecotoxicological effects, as chemical analysis cannot directly assess the combined effects (antagonistic or
synergistic) and the bioavailability of toxicants to organisms. Thereby, numerous indices (e.g., enrichment factor
(EF), contamination factor (CF), geoaccumulation index (Igeo), toxicity indices and ecological risk indices) have
been developed and utilised worldwide to assess extent and hazard of anthropogenic contamination by heavy
metals (Caeiro et al. 2005; Sekabira et al. 2010). Empirical sediment quality guidelines (SQGs), such as the
threshold/probable effect level (TEL/PEL) and the effect range low/median (ERL/ERM), are also commonly
used worldwide as informal benchmarks to aid in the interpretation of sediment chemistry data. These SQGs
evaluate the degree to which the sediment-associated chemical status might adversely affect aquatic organisms
and are designed to assist the interpretation of sediment quality (Wenning and Ingersoll 2002). However, their
assessment is based on the bulk (total) concentration of contaminants in sediments, which does not necessarily
reflect the bioavailable fraction of contaminants. Furthermore, bioavailability for a same contaminant changes
according to site conditions and benthic populations (Batley et al. 2005; Burton 2013; Campana et al. 2013). In
order to provide information on the ecological impact of sediment contamination on aquatic biota, sediment
toxicity bioassays were recommended (Long and Chapman 1985). Bioassays based on the inhibition of
bioluminescence of the marine bacterium Vibrio fischeri have gained popularity in sediment toxicity testing
using variable sediment fractions: aqueous elutriates, organic extracts, pore water or bulk sediment suspensions
(Ankley et al. 1991; Heida and Van der Oost 1996; Svenson et al. 1996; Salizzato et al. 1998). Also, SOS
Chromotest with the Escherichia coli PQ37 strain was widely used to test genotoxicity of sediments (Cachot et
al. 2006; Parrella et al. 2013). Two bioassays were carried out in this study: the Microtox ® was applied to
measure acute toxicity of sediment organic extracts and aqueous elutriates. The SOS-Chromotest (Quillardet et
al. 1982) was applied for measuring the genotoxic potency of sediment organic extracts. The use of elutriates
(aqueous extracts) can provides information on the potential toxic effects of leached contaminants released from
dredged material (Cheung et al. 1997; Wong et al. 1999), but are unlikely to provide information on the possible
effects of contaminants retained on the solid phase and deposited on the seabed. Organic solvent extraction
allows extraction of most organic pollutants adsorbed onto particulate matter. A major drawback of assaying
sediment toxicity is that the toxicity of the extracts may not be the result of anthropogenic contamination alone.
Common macrocompounds (e.g. ammonia and sulphur) derived from the natural decomposition of organic
matter can accumulate in sediments and cause toxic effects once they are made bioavailable through the

extraction process (Gagné et al. 1999). After consideration of each test phase, it appears clearly that testing many
exposure routes is necessary for a more comprehensive assessment of sediment toxicity.
To our knowledge, there are no studies assessing anthropogenic influences on sediment chemical
composition using such indices in Bizerte lagoon. Also, the assessment and monitoring of sediment quality in the
Bizerte lagoon, is predominantly reliant on chemical analyses, and up to date there are no data available
combining chemical analyses and toxicological assays. Taking that into account, the objectives of this study
were (i) to determine concentrations and spatial distributions of heavy metals in surface sediments of the Bizerte
lagoon; (ii) to explore the degree of heavy metal contamination in the lagoon using contamination indices; (iii) to
evaluate the toxicity and genotoxicity of sediments using two bioassays, Microtox ® and SOS-Chromotest,
respectively; (iv) to assess environmental risks of these metals in the studied area using sediment quality
guidelines (SQGs), and (v) to assess correlation analysis among heavy metals, and between heavy metals,
physico-chemical variables and biological endpoints.
Materials and methods
Study area
The Bizerte lagoon is a large Mediterranean brackish water area of 128 km 2 located in the North part of Tunisia
(latitude, 37°80′-37°14′ N; longitude, 9°46′-9°56′ E). It is the second largest lagoon in Tunisia with a mean
depth of 7 m and constitutes one of the first local lentic ecosystems for fisheries and mussel production. This
lagoon is linked to the Mediterranean Sea via a 7 km long canal and to the Ichkeul Lake by the Tinja River. The
main tributaries of this lagoon are the rivers Tinja, Mrezig, Garek, Ben Hassine, and Gueniche (Fig. 1). The
lagoon is subjected to the influence of several physical factors that strongly fluctuate during the year. The most
frequent and strongest winds are north-westerly, with a frequency of 200 days.year −1 and an average speed of
6−8 m.s −1 (Ouakad 2007). In the shallowest areas of the lagoon, the highest magnitude wind-mixing events can
thus supply enough energy to resuspend the superficial layer of the sediment. In winter, winds induce a vertical
mixture of the water column. At the same time rains are strong, and the freshwater flow coming from the Ichkeul
Lake is important. On the other hand, in summer, inputs of seawater into the lagoon are important and the water
column warming can induce its stratification (Sakka Hlaili et al. 2003). The Bizerte lagoon is subjected to
urbanization, industry, agriculture and aquaculture, as well as treated and untreated municipal sewages (Louati et

al. 2013). The human population around the lagoon is estimated at 163,000 inhabitants (2004 census) of which
approximately % are concentrated in the city of Bizerte. The other main important towns bordering the
lagoon are Menzel Bourguiba (which has a naval port and a metal factory), Menzel Abderrahman, and Menzel
Jemil. Some other industries including an iron and steel plant, a cement factory, a refinery, and boatyards,
textiles, plastics, and tire production factories are established nearby (Essid and Aissa 2002). The majority of
these surrounding towns and industries discharge their waste into the lagoon. The exchange of water between the
Mediterranean and the lake determines the salinity of the lagoon, which varies between 32.5 and 38.5‰. The
water temperature at the sub-surface range between 10 °C during winter (wet season) and 29 °C in summer time
(dry season).
Sediments sampling
Surface sediment samples (0-10 cm) were collected in March 2011 from nine stations in triplicate (nearly 500 g
for each), using a stainless steel grab. Details of the sampling sites are shown in Fig. 1 and Table 1. Sites were
selected to be representative of the different anthropic pressures present in the study area, e.g. cement works,
metallurgical industry, boatyard, tyre production factories and agriculture. After collection, samples were
wrapped in aluminium foil and cool transported to the laboratory where they were immediately stored in a
freezer at -20 °C. All sediment samples were freeze-dried, then sieved using a 2-mm mesh to eliminate debris,
homogenized and stored at 4 °C prior to being characterized with bioassays and chemical analysis.
Physico-chemical characterisation of sediments
All sampling sediments were subjected to physical and chemical analyses in order to determine their natural
characteristics (Table 1). The following physico-chemical water properties were determined in situ at all nine
stations using a WTW-197i multimeter: temperature, salinity and pH (pH H2O ). The pH of the sampled sediments
(pH sed ) was measured by shaking an aliquot of sediment in distilled water (10 g of dry sediment in 25 ml of
water) for 10 min. The suspension was left to stand for 10 min. The pH of the supernatant was measured with an
electronic pH meter (CONSORT P902, SCIENTIFIC Instruments, Belgium). The percentage of the finer grain
size fraction (<63 μm) was determined gravimetrically after wet sieving (Savinov et al. 2000). Total organic
carbon (TOC) content was determined by combustion in an LECO CS 125 analyzer (Etcheber et al. 2007). Dried
and homogenized sediment samples were acidified in crucibles with 2 N HCl to destroy carbonates, then dried at
60 °C to remove inorganic carbon and most of the remaining acid residues and water. Analyses were performed
by direct combustion in an induction furnace, and the CO 2 formed was determined quantitatively by infrared
absorption. TOC content is expressed as a percentage of dry weight (dw) sediment. Sulfur (S) was measured in
sediment samples using an HORIBA model EMIA-220V C/S analyzer with a resistance furnace and a infrared
detector. About 0.2 g of sample, mixed with 1 g of granular tin, was combusted in the analyzer to produce SO at
1350 °C. For the organic pollutant analysis (PAHs, PCBs, OCPs), sediments were freeze-dried, homogenised
and extracted with an Accelerated Solvent Extraction system (ASE) using dichloromethane (DCM). Details of
the protocols for the extraction, cleanup and analysis of POPs are described in Barhoumi et al. (2014a, b).
Potentially hazardous trace metallic elements (Hg, Cd, Cr, Cu, Pb, Zn, and Ni) and major elements (Fe and
Mn) contents in the sediment were determined after digestion of the samples with aqua regia according to FAO
(1975). Samples (0.5 g dw) were digested with a mixture of HCl (37 %) and HNO 3 (69 %) in a ratio of 3:1 (v/v)
at 120 °C under reflux conditions. The obtained suspension was then filtered through a membrane of 0.45 μm
pore-diameter, diluted to 50 mL with ultra -pure water, and analysed using a Jobin-Yvon Ultima-C inductively
coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometer (ICP-AES). The reagent blanks were monitored throughout the
analysis and were used to accredit the analytical results. Standard reference material IAEA-SL-1 (Lake
sediment) was analysed at the same time to ensure quality control and accuracy of the analysis. The
concentrations measured for the reference sediment were in agreement with the certified values (accuracy <10
%).
Sample preparation
Elutriate
The protocol applied for sediment elutriate preparation (water-extractable phase) was a derivation of
Environment Canada (1992): 30 mL 2% NaCl solution was added to 6 g dw sediment. The sediment-water
suspension was agitated vigorously on a magnetic stirrer for 15 min and centrifuged at 300 g for 10 min at 15 °C.
The supernatant was collected as elutriate and pH was measured following filtration through a 0.45 µm filter.
The elutriate was stored at 4 °C in the dark prior to toxicity testing (Microtox ® Acute Toxicity 100% Test),
which was conducted within 24 h of preparation.

Organic extract
For the preparation of organic extracts, g freeze-dried sediment from each of the nine sampling stations was
separately extracted with dichloromethane (Fluka, Buchs, Switzerland) using an ASE 200 accelerated solvent
extractor (Dionex, France). The parameters used during the extraction procedure were as follows: temperature
(100 °C), static time (8 min), pressure (100 bars), heating time (5 min), flush volume (60%), and purge time (60
s). The volume of the resulting Dichloromethane-dissolved extract was reduced by using a RapidVap evaporator
(Labconco, Kansas City, MO, USA). Extracts were concentrated to dryness with N 2 and resuspended in 200 µL
of dimethyl sulphoxide (DMSO, Sigma). A blank of extraction was prepared by the same procedure but without
sediment.
Bioassays and exposure conditions
Microtox ®
Two Microtox ® protocols were applied for sediment acute toxicity testing; the 100% Test on sediment aqueous
extract (Elutriate), and the Basic Test on sediment organic extracts.
Microtox ® is a commercial toxicity bioassay based on the reduction in bioluminescence of the marine
bacterium Vibrio fischeri following exposure to toxicants. Both the Microtox 100% Test and the Microtox Basic
Test were used following the standard procedures (AZUR Environmental 1998; ISO 1999). These toxicity tests
were conducted with a Model 500 analyzer (Kontron Instruments, Montigny le Bretonneux) and lyophilized
bacteria cultures (Acute Reagent, Modern Water, Guildford, UK). A basic test was conducted with the reference
standard potassium dichromate (200 mg L -1 K 2 Cr 2 O 7 ) for each fresh vial of bacteria to ensure validity of the test
method. The Microtox ® data acquisition software was used to calculate the EC50 (%) value, the effective
concentration of sample (expressed as mg of dw sediment) causing a 50% decrease in the light output.
The 100% Microtox Test was performed on four serial 1:2 dilutions of each elutriate starting with undiluted
elutriate (100% elutriate). Each assay was then inoculated with 10 μl of freshly resuspended freeze-dried bacteria
in 2% NaCl. Each assay was run in duplicate. Bioluminescence was measured after 5, 15 and 30 min of exposure
and compared with blank (NaCl 2%), and corrected for spontaneous decline in photoactivity.
The Microtox ® Basic Test was performed on four serial 1:2 dilutions of sediment organic extracts starting
with 10 µL/mL of organic extract (1%). Each assay was then inoculated with 10 μl of freshly resuspended
freeze-dried bacteria in 2% NaCl. After 5, 15 and 30 min incubation, the bioluminescence was measured,

compared with a blank, and corrected for spontaneous decline in photoactivity. One control solvent (1% v/v
DMSO) and one saline blank were run with each serie of samples. All samples were tested in duplicate.
Sediment samples were ranked using the following scale: samples having an inhibition percentage at 30 min
less than or equal to 20% were considered no toxic and an inhibition percentage between 20-40%, 40-80%, and
>80% were considered slightly, moderately and highly toxic, respectively.
SOS-Chromotest
For detection of direct and indirect acting genotoxicant in sediments the SOS-Chromotest (Quillardet and
Hofnung 1985) was performed using Escherichia coli PQ37 strain with and without addition of an S9
microsomal fraction obtained from the livers of Sprague-Dawley rats treated with β-naphthoflavone
andphenobarbital (Xenotech). In each series of tests, a solvent control (0.1% v/v DMSO), a blank of extraction
and a B[a]P positive control (0.5 µg mL −1 ) were analysed. Responses were expressed as mean induction factor
(three replicates) for 25 mg equivalent dry weight sediment per assay. Samples with significant SOS induction
factor compare to control solvent were considered as genotoxic when values exceeded 2, moderately genotoxic
when values were in the range 1.5-2.0, slightly genotoxic when it was comprised between 1.0 and 1.5, and not
genotoxic when values were less than or equal to 1.0 (Mersch-Sundermann et al. 1992).
Assessment of sediment contamination
In the interpretation of geochemical data, choice of background values plays an important role (Memet 2011).
The best alternative is to compare concentrations between contaminated and mineralogically and texturally
comparable, uncontaminated sediments (Rubio et al. 2000). Since there were no data on background
concentrations for the investigated Bizerte sediments of close areas, the average crust values obtained by Martin
and Whitfield (1983) were used as reference baseline for the elements. In this study, two indices were used to
assess the degree of heavy metal contamination in sediments of the Bizerte lagoon.

Enrichment factor (EF)
Enrichment factor (EF) has been widely reported as an important tool to differentiate between anthropogenic and
natural metal sources in the sediment (Nolting et al. 1999; Selvaraj et al. 2004; Naji and Ismail 2011). Aluminum
(Al) and iron (Fe) are two main elements used as normalizers for EF computation. Al concentration was not
analyzed in the studied sediments. Therefore, Fe was used to calculate metal enrichment factor. This element is

As suggested by Wang et al. (2008) 0.5≤EF≤1.5, indicates metal input from natural weathering process, and
EF>1.5, indicates metal input from anthropogenic sources or a greater percentage from non-natural weathering
process. However, the degree of enrichment was interpreted as proposed by Birch (2003). EF<1 indicates no
enrichment, 1<EF<3 indicates minor enrichment, 3≤EF≤5 indicates moderate enrichment, 5≤EF≤10 indicates
moderate to severe enrichment, 10≤EF≤25 indicates severe enrichment, 25≤ EF≤50 indicates very severe
enrichment, and EF>50 suggests extremely severe enrichment.
Sediment quality guidelines
Sediment quality assessment guidelines (SQGs) are very useful to evaluate sediment contamination by
comparing sediment contaminant concentration with the corresponding quality guideline (MacDonald et al.

2000). These guidelines evaluate the degree to which the sediment-associated chemicals might adversely affect
aquatic organisms and are designed to assist in the interpretation of sediment quality.
Two sets of SQGs developed for freshwater ecosystems (MacDonald et al. 2000) were applied in this study
to evaluate the ecological risks caused by heavy metals in sediments: the effect range low (ERL)/effect range
median (ERM) and the threshold effect level (TEL)/probable effect level (PEL) values (Zheng et al. 2008). ERL
and TEL (low range values) are concentrations below which adverse effects are not expected to occur. In
contrast, the ERM and PEL are concentrations above which adverse effects are expected to occur more often
than not. Furthermore, toxic units (TUs) were used to normalize the toxicity of the various metals to allow
comparison of their relative effects, defined as the ratio of the determined content of each metal to the PEL
value. The ΣTU were used to estimate the potential acute toxicity of metals mixture in sediment samples
(Pedersen et al. 1998).
Data analysis
The results of chemical (metals) and bioassay (SOS-Chromotest) were reported as mean ± S.D. All statistical
analyses were performed using STATISTICA 7.1 from StatSoft (Maison Alfort, France). Data was initially
checked for normality (Shapiro-Wilk's test, 1% risk) and homogeneity of variances (Levene test, 5% risk). Then,
an ANOVA, followed by the post-hoc Tukey test was performed to determine differences between treatments. If
data transformation was not sufficient to perform parametric analysis, non-parametric Kruskall-Wallis ANOVA
and Bonferroni-Dunn's test were used (p<0.05). The existence and strength of relationships between parameters
(metals, PAHs, PCBs, OCPs, pH, fine particle (<63 µm), TOC, Sulfur, Microtox ® , SOS-Chromotest) were
determined by parametric Pearson's bivariate correlation analysis. The spatial distributions of each heavy metal,
indices and sediment toxicity were mapped with ARC-GIS desktop software.
Results and discussion
General characteristic of sediments
The results of the physicochemical characterisation of each sediment are presented in Table 1. Temperature and
salinity varied little between sites ranging from 13.3-15.4 °C and 34.6-35.5 psu, respectively. The pH is an

important indicator of environmental quality and pollution degree in a water system (Singh et al. 2005). In
leaching process of contaminated sediment the pH depends on the buffering capacity of the sediment. When pH
reaches a certain value, metals will start being released from sediments (Chen and Lin 2001). High pH values
generally decrease the solubility of heavy metals in water, while low pH values can actually weaken the strength
of metal association and impede the retention of metals by sediments (Avila-Pérez et al. 1999; Guven and Akinci
2013). In this study the sediments displayed an alkaline pH between 7.2 and 8.2 and, in this range, there was no
release of metals except for Mn, as reported by Chen and Lin (2001). The lowest pH (7.2) was determined in the
sediment taken immediately downstream of the Mrezig and Haima Rivers (S1, S2), and the highest value (8.2)
was measured in sediments collected in the center of the lagoon (S6, S7).
As it is well known, metals are not permanently bound to sediments, but can be remobilized by chemical and
biological agents both in the sediments and in the water column above (Stone and Droppo 1994; Filgueiras et al.
2004). For these reasons, measurements of pH in the water column above the sediments were made. pH of water
varied between 6.8 and 7.9 but was not significantly different from pH of sediment (Table 1). The small
difference between the pH of water and sediments can be explained by different factors, such as CO 2 leakage,
tidal flooding, bacterial activity, oxydo-redox equilibrium, sediment composition, etc. (Reddy and DeLaune
2008; Basallote et al. 2012). Since the Bizerte lagoon is rich in organic matter (Ouakad 2000; Ben Garali et al.
2013), the low pH values in the water column might be due to the decomposition of organic matter leading to the
release of various organic acids (Bowen 1979). Also, the CO 2 leakage scenario from high anthropogenic
activities (urbanization, industry, municipal sewages, agriculture and aquaculture...) around the lagoon may be
another reason of the slight acidification of the water column. The high pH of sediments is probably related to
microbial activity and more particularly to sulfate-reducing bacteriae which are present in sediments of the study
area (Ben Said et al. 2010). The Bizerte lagoon represents a fragile environment due to its enclosed nature and
the long residence time of pollutants (Harzallah 2003). In addition to these conditions, the high content of
organic matter in this lagoon can lead to oxygen depletion in sediments. Once anoxic conditions are established,
anaerobic bacterial strains reduce sulfate in sulfides. The massive production of sulfides increases the pH of
sediments (Heitmann and Blodau 2006). Increase in the pH of sediments due to sulfate reduction has been
widely documented in various natural sediments (Abd-el-Malek and Rizk 1963; Mills and Herlihy, 1985;
Kharaka et al. 1994; Michael et al. 2015).
Sediment grain size and water depth varied within the lagoon. As shows in Table 1, a high percentage of sand
was found at stations S1 and S4 located at the edges of the lagoon, which has shallow water (2.5 and 3 m,
respectively). The waves and currents at these sites are highly active and can disturb the fine particles deposition.
However, silt and clay are dominant in other stations, where the water depth is high and the wave slightly lower,
which favors the precipitation of fine particles. The abundance of fine particles was assumed to come from
anthropogenic inputs associated with the erosion of surrounding agricultural areas. This result was consistent
with the findings of Mouldi et al. (2008) and Boufahja (2010) who showed that the surface sediments of the
Bizerte lagoon are mostly composed of silt and clay fractions.
Total organic carbon (TOC) content ranges from 0.7 to 2.2%. The highest value was observed at station S2
and was probably related to the high occurrence of urban and industrial wastewater discharges, which are rich in
organic matter. Sulfur (S) was homogeneously distributed in the lagoon (0.3 to 0.8%), except for stations S2, S4
and S5, where higher contents were found (2.3, 1.1 and 3.1%, respectively).
Heavy metals in sediments of the Bizerte lagoon
Table 2 summarizes the major and the trace elements' concentrations in the sediments from the nine locations of
the Bizerte lagoon. Spatial distribution map of each element is shown in Fig. 2. The heavy metal concentrations
in surface sediments (expressed in mg kg -1 sediment dw) from the studied area varied from 0.3 to 1.1 for Cd, 7.2
to 30.8 for Cr, 4.0 to 45.2 for Cu, 71.1 to 239.6 for Mn, 62.8 to 177.5 for Pb, 73.8 to 240.7 for Ni, 318.6 to
1825.5 for Zn and 4209.4 to 17215.5 for Fe. At all sampling stations, concentrations of Hg were below detection
limits. The distribution of these heavy metals showed large spatial variations among the stations as a result of
variability in the extent of source input of trace metals. This heterogeneous profile had already been reported in
the Bizerte lagoon sediments by other authors (Srarfi 2007; Ben Garali et al. 2010; Ben-Khedher et al. 2013).
The average concentrations of heavy metals mentioned above are in the following order (mg kg -1 ): Hg (< LD) <
Cd (1 ± 0.2) < Cr (22 ± 7.8) < Cu (23 ± 14.4) < Pb (118 ± 53.5) < Ni (143 ± 54.5) < Mn (176 ± 61.6) < Zn (834
± 462.0) < Fe (13428 ± 4732.1). The results were only partly in agreement compatible with previous studies
(Boufahja et al. 2007; Ben Khedher et al. 2013) conducted in the Bizerte lagoon. Boufahja et al. (2007) found
that Fe was the most abundant in the sediment, followed by Mn and Zn, and the least was Cu, while Cd, Cr and
Hg were not analyzed. Ben Khedher et al. (2013) reported that the accumulation order of heavy metals in the
sediment samples was Fe > Zn > Mn > Pb > Cr > Cu > Ni > Cd.
Spatial analysis showed that the site with the highest amount of heavy metals (Σmetals) was S6, followed by
S3 (Table 2). The sediments of both stations were mainly composed of fine particles (90.2 and 89.5%,
respectively), which may enhance the adsorption process and then sediment accumulation of trace elements due
to the high specific surface of fine particles (Oliveira et al. 2011). According to this observation, sediment at S1,
with a lower TOC content, and mainly composed of coarse material, contained lower amounts of heavy metals.
This feature can be explained by its lower adsorption capacity. Low heavy metals content at S1 may be also
explained by strong hydrodynamism at this station located at the exchange point between the lagoon of Bizerte
and the Mediterranean Sea. The hydrodynamic conditions are important factors that affect the physical properties
of sediments; furthermore, they affect the concentration and spatial distribution of heavy metals (Peng et al.
2004). In this study, total metal concentrations followed the order of station S6 > S3 > S7 > S9 > S8 > S5 > S2 >
S4 > S1.
Along with particle size distribution and hydrodynamics, the proximity of contaminant sources plays an
important role in the distribution of the heavy metal concentrations in the Bizerte lagoon surface sediments.
Thereby, stations S6 and S3 located near the city of Menzel Bourguiba and Menzel Jemil showed an overall high
metal concentrations which could be due to the influence of active anthropogenic activities in the adjacent areas
including a number of sewerage systems and a metallurgic industry discharging domestic and industrial effluents
in to the lagoon. Altogether, industries and urban sources generate a daily average flow of wastewater of about
31,600 and 20,000 m 3 /day in the Bizerte Lagoon, respectively (MAERH 2003). Yoshida et al. (2002) measured
concentrations of heavy metal in bottom sediments of the Bizerte lagoon. They found high concentration in sites
situated nearby the landfill of Menzel Bourguiba (station S6). Our results confirm the relatively high metal
contamination of the Menzel Bourguiba's station found by Yoshida et al. (2002).
The highest concentrations were found for Fe, Zn, Mn, Ni and Pb. The elements Pb and Zn were generally
regarded as the identified elements of traffic pollution (Paterson et al. 1999; Dai 2001). The commercial ships
and small boats (for fishing) which use diesel as fuel are among the main vehicles in the Bizerte lagoon for
heavy metals. Therefore, traffic transportation might be a potential source of heavy metals in the study area. In
addition, antifouling paints used in boat maintenance in the south-western sector (SOCOMENA, society) of the
lagoon could be another source of Cu and Zn in surface sediments. Turner (2010) has demonstrated that
antifouling paint can be a source of Cu, Cd, Pb and Zn increase in sediments and emphasizes that release of
those metals is generated during boat maintenance and cleaning. Mn and Fe are considered particle size proxies
because they are conservative elements and a major constituent of clay minerals (Rubio et al. 2000; Aloupi and
Angelidis 2001; Burton et al. 2005). In addition, their gradients in the lagoon can be related to continental inputs
of matter from urban drainages. Nickel is very widespread at stations (S4, S6 and S8) situated close to the
industrial zones of Menzel Bourguiba and Menzel Jemil. Contamination of the Bizerte lagoon by Ni was also
observed in a precedent research study and was attributed to the closeness of the industrial zone (Yoshida et al.
2002; Ben Garali et al. 2010).
According to the study of industrial pollution control carried out in 1998, the amount of heavy metals
produced by the industrial sector in the Bizerte region is estimated at 141 tons / year (MAERH 2003). The main
pollution sources of heavy metals are: the steel complex -El Fouledh‖ and the society of maintenance and
construction of ships (SOCOMENA) at the city of Menzel Bourguiba; the factories of bolts (MATUBO) and
manufacturing of Spinning, Weaving and Crafts (MAFILTA) at the city of Menzel Jemil and the cement factory
at the Bizerte city.
The comparison of our results with those of the 1988-2010 campaigns (Kamens et al. 1989; Boufahja et al.
2007; El Ati Hellal et al. 2011; Ben Khedher et al. 2013) reveals an overall significant increase of Cd, Cu, Pb, Zn
and Ni concentrations in the sediments of the Bizerte lagoon (Table 3). During the 22 years time span, the
average concentrations of Cd and Cu were increased two-fold, while for Pb, Zn and Ni they were increased
three-fold, four-fold and twelve-fold, respectively. In contrast, the concentrations of Cr, Mn and Fe did not show
remarkable long-term changes. Our results indicate that the heavy metals content in the sediments of the Bizerte
lagoon is strongly affected in recent years by Cd, Cu, Pb, Zn and Ni emissions, outcome of the increasing
development of various industrial, agricultural and urban activities located around the lagoon. To gain a
comprehensive understanding of the degree of contamination of the Bizerte lagoon, a comparison of the heavy
metal concentrations with the average crust values and other regions was performed (Table 3). In surface
sediments from the Bizerte lagoon, the mean total contents of Cd, Pb, Ni and Zn were clearly higher with respect
to the average crust values. Compared to the data published for other regions, the metal contamination data for
the Bizerte lagoon indicated that the sediment was not as severely contaminated with Cd, Cr, Cu, Mn, Pb, Ni,
Hg, Zn, and Fe. The metal contamination in the sediment of the Bizerte lagoon was less severe than that of the
Pearl Sfax-Kerkennah plateau (Tunisia), Odiel-Tintod Estuary (Spain), Cishan River (China), and Golden Horn
Estuary (Turkey); however, it was worse than the contamination of the Daya Bay (China), Southern California
coastal shelf (USA) and Campeche shelf (Mexico). All of these regions have high population densities and
intense economic activity, and they received effluents from many of the industrial areas, sewage from a number
of major cities and agricultural runoff. Therefore, heavy metal pollution, which is introduced through rivers,
runoff, and land-based point sources, is very common in estuarine, lagoons and coastal regions (Christophoridis
et al. 2009; Qiao et al. 2013).

Indices of sediment contamination
The results of computed geoaccumulation index (Igeo) values are regrouped in Table and their spatial
distributions in sediments are presented in Fig. 3. This index consists of seven classes in relation to pollution
extent. According to Igeo values, sediments of Bizerte lagoon can be considered as unpolluted to moderately
polluted with Cd and Ni, unpolluted to strongly polluted with Zn and moderately to strongly polluted with Pb.
However, Cr, Cu, Mn and Fe, characterized by negative Igeo values, indicating absence of pollution by these
elements.
Contamination and possible anthropogenic impacts on the surface sediment in Bizerte lagoon was also
assessed using enrichment factor (EF). The mean EFs were calculated with respect to average crust (Martin and
Whitfield 1983) and are shown in Table 5. Their distribution patterns are illustrated in Fig. 4. The mean EF
values for all metals studied except Cr and Mn were >1.5, suggesting anthropogenic discharges of metal in the
lagoon. The highest EF values were found at station S4. The EF values for Zn and Pb in the sediments of this
station were 72.0 and 66.1, respectively, indicating -extremely severe enrichment‖. The EF values for Ni and Cd
were between 10 and 25, indicating -severe enrichment‖. The EF value for Cu at station S4 was 5.9, indicating
-moderate to severe enrichment‖. However, no enrichment (EF<1) was found for Cr and Mn whatever the
considered station. Zn had the highest EF value among the eight metals studied, followed by Pb. Lead at all
stations except S4 and S9 had the highest EF values among the eight metals studied. The EF values for other
studied metals indicated -minor to very severe enrichment‖ of sediments. Stations were ranked according to their
total EF values according to the following order: S4 > S1 > S8 > S7 > S2 > S9 > S5 > S6 > S3.
Considering the mean Igeo and EF values of heavy metals, it can be deduce that the Bizerte lagoon surface
sediments are highly polluted with Cd, Pb, Ni and Zn and therefore require urgent action from appropriate
quarters. According to these two contamination indices, station S4 appears as the most contaminated by trace
elements. This result is not surprising, since this station is located near the Menzel Jemil city with high
anthropogenic activities.
Sediment toxicity
We applied the Microtox ® Basic Test to evaluate the toxicity of sediment organic extracts from the nine
sampling stations studied. This bioassay was carried in order to provide information about the nonpolar
compounds, which are poorly available for pelagic organisms but can still exert adverse effects on benthic
dwelling organisms. In the concentration range tested (from 25 to 25x10 -5 g dw equivalent sediment), all

sediment organic extracts were very toxic to V. fischeri strain and caused 100% inhibition of bioluminescence
(data not shown). This toxicity can be related to presence of various organic pollutants in sediment of the Bizerte
lagoon in particular, PAHs, PCBs, organochlorinated pesticides (Barhoumi et al. 2014a, b). Using the Microtox ®
Basic Test, Salizzato et al. (1998) showed high toxicity for PAHs and PCBs to V. fischeri.
The Microtox 100% test was also used to evaluate the toxicity of sediment aqueous extracts (Elutriate). The
results expressed as milligrams dw of sediment are presented in Table 6 and the spatial distribution of acute
toxicity is depicted in Fig. 5a. At all stations, the EC50 (%) value was higher than 200 mg equivalent dry
sediment per mL -1 . The most toxic sediment aqueous extract was collected from stations S1, S4 and S9, with an
inhibition percentage between 20 and 40 % for 30 min exposure. The other samples are considered as no toxic
(inhibition below 20% for 30 min exposure). In contrast to S1, S4, S5, S7 and S9 extracts which showed an
increase in toxicity with increase exposure time, the S2, S3, S6 and S8 elutriates did not show time-dependent
increase/decrease in toxicity. Based on these results, the toxicity gradient decreases in the following order:
S1=S4=S9 > S3=S7 > S2=S5=S6=S8. Generally speaking, the elutriates prepared from sediments from the nine
sampled stations of the Bizerte lagoon exhibited a slight toxicity in the Microtox ® 100 % test. Data from
chemical analysis showed no significant correlation between metals content of sediment and acute toxicity of
elutriates. This poor correlation could be explained by the low metal bioavailability in aqueous extracts due to
the presence of a high content of organic matter in the Bizerte lagoon (Ouakad 2000; Ben Garali et al. 2013).
Campbell et al. (1988) showed that the presence of organic matter increases the retention of metals by the
formation of stable complexes between metal-clay-organic matter or metal-organic matter-clay. Also, high
content of organic matter may increase the Acid-volatile sulfides (AVS), which is an important carrier phase for
metals (Di Toro et al. 1990; Zheng and Xu 2003). Indeed, several studies have demonstrated an inverse
relationship between acute sediment toxicity and AVS in marine sediments (Di Toro et al. 1990; Ankley et al.
1991). When the levels of AVS increase, the binding of metals with sulfides increase, consequently, the
bioavailability of metals decreases. Concentrations of AVS within sediments depend on several factors including
organic matter supply, pH, temperature, particle size, sulfate reduction levels, and sediment redox conditions
(Gambrell 1994; Oehm et al. 1997; Liu et al. 2010).
In the same manner as metals content, acute toxicity of elutriates was not correlated to organic contaminants
accumulated in sediments. Toxicity of sediments may have resulted from additional components and
contaminants not analysed in the present study and the possible occurrence of synergistic or antagonistic
interactions between constituents present in sediment. For instance, organotins were not analysed in the present
study but have been detected at high concentrations (200 µg kg -1 ) in sediments from the Bizerte lagoon
(Mzoughi et al. 2005). Stasinakis et al. (2001) noted an inhibition of respiration rate of activated sludge
heterotrophic micro-organisms with increasing exposure time to tributyltin, dibutyltin and triphenyltin. The
hypothesis of the intervention of other none analysed toxicants was confirmed by the sediment of station S1
which induced a high toxic effect to V. fischeri, despite having lower major and trace elements' concentrations.
While it was not possible to correlate the observed toxic effects with any of the measured contaminants, it is
notable that station S4 which exhibits slight elutriate toxicity was consistently ranked the most polluted with all
contamination indices.
Elutriate testing was useful in exposing bacteria to water-soluble substances, which provided a realistic
estimation of pollutant bioavailability (Harkey et al. 1994). Unfortunately, the main limitations of this kind of
assay are the poor extraction efficiency of nonpolar compounds such as PCBs and polyaromatic hydrocarbons
and the toxicity measurement of only extractible and hydrosoluble compounds (Harkey et al. 1994).
Generally speaking, it seems clear that testing sediment toxicity using organic extracts with Microtox ®
bioassay could provide a better estimation of global toxicity than using elutriates. Similar results were observed
by Grant and Briggs (2002).
Genotoxicity
Genotoxicity of sediment organic extracts were analysed by the SOS Chromotest with and without S9 metabolic
activation system for detection of indirect and direct acting genotoxicants, respectively. Fig. 5b shows the spatial
distribution of the genotoxic potential of surface sediments of the Bizerte lagoon. In the absence of the S9
microsomal fraction, the sediment extracts from station S1, S3 and S6 show significant differences compared to
station S7 (p<0.01). In the presence of the S9 microsomal fraction, the sediment extracts from station S1 and S7
show significant differences compared to stations S2, S4, S5, S6 and S8 (p<0.01). Also, S3 was significantly
different from S4 and S8 (p<0.01). According to Mersch-Sundermann et al. (1992), sediment extracts from S1,
S3 and S7 were moderately genotoxic (1.5<IF<2), and from slightly to no genotoxic from S2, S4, S5, S6, S8 and
S9 (with S9 microsomal fraction). In addition, sediments from station S1, S3 and S7 contained only pro-
genotoxic organic compounds since no genotoxic response was obtained without addition of an S9 microsomal
fraction. Bacterial assays have been widely used to assess the genotoxicity of suspended or bottom sediments
(reviewed in Chen and White 2004). The SOS responses obtained for the Bizerte lagoon with S9, ranged from
0.79 to 1.95 IF per gram of dw sediment. Those values were of the same order of magnitude, albeit slightly

lower, than those reported for sediments of the Seine estuary (Cachot et al. 2006). However, they are much lower
than found by Parrella et al. (2013) in the porewaters of two river basins in southern Italy. Previously reported
data (Dutka et al. 1996; Cachot et al. 2006) on the river sediments showed that PAHs and other POPs such as
PCBs and OCPs are pro-genotoxicants. In this study, sediments of stations S7 and S3 presented low content of
these compounds. So, the observed genotoxicity after the addition the S9 microsomal fraction may have resulted
from additional components and contaminants not analysed in the present study. Data from chemical analysis
showed also no significant correlation between any of the contaminants analyzed and genotoxicity of sediment
extracts.
Toxicity assessment of heavy metals in sediments based on the
SQGs
Several sediment quality guidelines (SQGs; including sediment quality criteria, sediment quality objectives, and
sediment quality standards) have been developed to assess the ecotoxicological hazard of trace elements in
sediments (MacDonald et al. 2000), such as effect range low (ERL) and effect range median (ERM), threshold
effect level (TEL) and probable effect level (PEL) values (Table 2). Three ranges in chemical concentrations
were defined, where adverse effects are observed rarely (<ERL or <TEL), occasionally (ERL-ERM or TEL-
PEL) and frequently (>ERM or >PEL). Sediment quality was predicted according to sediment quality guideline
levels for studied metals (Fig. 6). At almost all stations, the concentrations of Ni and Zn exceeded the PEL and
ERM values, indicating possible adverse effects of these metals. Although concentrations of Cd and Cr were
below the TEL and ERL values, Cd concentrations at 90% sites being between the TEL and PEL might cause
adverse effects occasionally. For other metals, 30% of sites were greater than PEL for Pb and 30% of sites were
being between the TEL and PEL for Cu, which also indicated a potential harm for benthic organisms.
Fig. 7 shows the mean toxic unit values (TU) and the sum of toxic units (ΣTU) of six heavy metals in
sediments from the Bizerte lagoon. The average toxic unit values of Cd, Cr, Cu, Pb, Ni and Zn in the studied
sediments were 0.21, 0.13, 0.21, 1.03, 3.34 and 3.08, respectively. The average ΣTU of these heavy metals was
always above 4 indicating moderate toxicity to sediment-dwelling fauna whatever the considered sediment
(Pedersen et al. 1998). Ni and Zn had higher contribution to ΣTU values, indicating that the sediment toxicity
was mainly ascribed to Zn and Ni. Copper contributed the least to ΣTU. The highest ΣTU value (14.9) was
observed at station S4 near the Menzel Jemil city, whereas the lowest ΣTU value (5.3) appeared at the exchange
point S1.

Pearson's correlation analysis
Correlation coefficients for phyciso-chemical and toxicological parameters are presented in. From this table, the
heavy metals Ni, Zn and Pb are positively correlated among themselves. Also Fe was highly correlated with Cr
and Mn. Contents of Cd and Cu were not correlated with none of the studied metals. According to Suresh et al.
(2011b), if the correlation coefficient between the metals is higher, metals have common sources, mutual
dependence and identical behavior during their transport. The absence of correlation among the other metals
suggests that the contents of these metals are not controlled by a single factor. However it is controlled by a
combination of geochemical support phases and their mixed associations. In the present study, Ni, Zn and Pb, on
one hand, and Fe, Cr and Mn on other hand, have common source whereas others have not.
The importance of physical and chemical properties of sediments, including the particle size distribution and
organic carbon in total sorption capacity for heavy metals and toxic potential of sediments, have been
documented in previous studies (Baptista Neto et al. 2000; Lin et al. 2002; Huang and Lin 2003). In some field
studies, strong correlations have been found between heavy metals and TOC content (Zabetoglou et al. 2002;
Neto et al. 2006), but there are also several field studies including this one in which the relationship between
concentrations of heavy metal and TOC is not so strong. The absence of correlation is sometimes considered as
an indicator of anthropogenic pollution; it has been documented that results from sites with high concentrations
of contaminants can distort and mask the correlation relationship with TOC (Evans et al. 1989). In contrast to
TOC, the mud (silt and clay) content of the studied sediments showed a significant positive correlation with Cd,
Cr, Mn, Fe and Σmetals, suggesting that the highest metal concentrations are associated with the fine-grained
sediments of the study area, as these components are more readily adsorbed on clay minerals.
The strong correlation (r>0.90, p<0.001) between Ni, Zn and Pb contents with the sum of toxic units (ΣTU),
indicated a high contribution of these three metals to ΣTU, as shown above.
Based on the results obtained in the present study, it can be concluded that deriving the potential toxicity of
sediments from the comparison of single contaminants with SQGs is a simplistic approach, as it does not take
into account the interaction between contaminants (e.g. antagonism, synergism and additive effects) and the
bioavailability of these contaminants, which can be the main causes of the potential toxicity (Chapman and
Mann 1999; Burton 2002; Choueri et al. 2009). This could explain the poor correlation (p>0.05) observed in this
study between potential toxicity, based on comparison with SQG values, and global toxicity, based on the results
of bioassays. These findings highlight that SQGs can be used as a first line of evidence (e.g. Burton 2002;

Hübner et al. 2009) but that they should not be used alone for regulatory purposes (e.g. DelValls et al. 2004), as
decisions made based only on the results of the SQGs approach provides uncompleted conclusions.
The results from this study show clearly that it is important to carry out both chemical and ecotoxicological
analyses (SQGs and bioassays) to be able to correctly evaluate the potential toxicity and ecological risk of
sediments. Suter et al. (2000) and Fairbrother (2003) recommended that, within the ecological risk assessment
framework, multiple lines of evidence be evaluated to more fully characterize environmental risk of chemicals.
Conclusions
The study provides a baseline for the quality assessment of surface sediments from the Bizerte lagoon (North
Tunisia) using an integrated approach. The highest concentrations of heavy metals were found near urban areas
with high anthropogenic activities. Total heavy metal concentrations in the sediment samples followed the order:
Fe > Zn > Mn > Ni > Pb > Cu > Cr > Cd > Hg. Enrichment factor (EF) and geo-accumulation index (Igeo) were
successfully applied for the assessment of heavy metals pollution in sediments of the Bizerte lagoon. These
indices indicate a widespread pollution by Cd, Pb, Ni and Zn in the Bizerte lagoon sediments and show that these
heavy metals originate from anthropogenic sources -mainly urban runoffs and industrial effluent discharges.
Comparison of data from this study and previous works suggest there is a progressive increase in metal
contamination in surface sediment over the past 20 years.
Toxicity assessment of heavy metals in sediments based on the SQGs suggests that toxicity affected by Ni
and Zn would be expected frequently. The TUs showed a decrease in an order Ni > Zn > Pb > Cd=Cu > Cr. In
contrast, the Microtox ® assay showed that sediment aqueous extracts were not or weakly toxic suggesting a low
mobility of contaminants in sediments. This result highlights the absolute necessity of a combine chemical and
toxicological approach for a reliable environmental risk assessment of sediments samples.
